captions.text: [CAR ENGINE]

CHRIS HARRIS: Welcome to
the 2013 Mille Miglia.

This isn't really my world,
the world of old cars.

So I'm looking at a load of
amazing metal, much of which,

I don't know what it is,
but it's all stunning.

I suppose I have to just admit
that I'm thrilled to be here.

And I'm driving a C-type
with Al Buncombe.

As you can see, I'm a bit
befuddled, just because of the

sheer amount of machinery
on display.

There are apparently 422 cars
entered into this event, 1,000

miles driving them from Breacia
to Rome and back.
Or is it the other way around?
I can't remember.
It's a very special event.

And I really can't believe
the cars on display.

So let's have a look at some of
these cars before we go out
and do some driving.

Can you see this according
to scale?
I'm not a very big man.
That's not a very big car.

Can you imagine or even
contemplate driving this for
1,000 miles?

The great thing about the Mille
Miglia is it encourages

car companies that have a great
wealth of historical

cars in their archives to get
them out and use them, and
have them seen.

Mercedes Benz is here
with a load of SLs.

Porsche is here with
a few cars.

Jaguar, the team we're with,
got about four or five cars
entered, I think.

There's just so much
on display.

This is the car we'll be
driving, one of 55 C-type
Jaguars ever made.
First registered keeper--
a Mr. Juan Manuel Fangio.

It has around 290 horsepower,
weighs 900 kilograms, has drum

brakes all around, and uses
skinny Dunlop rubber.
It's a spin waiting to happen.
Hey, I'm joking.

Al regularly races it,
winning pretty much
everything he enters.
For me, this is crucial.

It's not a 60-year-old car being
rolled out for a jolly,

it's used hard and
maintained well.

This will pay dividends over
the next 1,000 miles.
That is the event--

1,000 miles from Breacia in
the north to Rome in the

south, and back up
to Breacia again.

Immortalized by Stirling Moss
with his seminal 10 hours and

7 minutes time, it was the
ultimate road race.

But it was stopped in 1957
after two fatal crashes.

Since then it's taken
many forms.

But from 1982 it's been
run as a road rally
with regularity stages.

These are effectively time
trials, where drive and

co-driver have to average
very precise speeds.
Sadly, they are slow speeds.

And, as you'll see, Al and I
will struggle to understand
going slowly.
[CAR ENGINE]
So it's not a race.

But the thing with the Millie
Miglia is it couldn't happen
anywhere other than Italy.

I thought I knew a bit about
making time on public roads,

but I was about to learn
a whole lot more.

The Jaguar team is basically a
load of celebs and, hm, me.

Model David Gandy has
every woman in the
two-mile radius, giggling.

Yasmin Le Bon loves
her driving.

Andy Wallace won them all in a
Jag and is a complete legend.

Sir Chris Hoy is a hopeless
petrol-head.

And I'm told that Daniel Day
Lewis is quite handy at
something called acting.

Strangely, myself and Al
aren't asked for many
interviews.

Now, as many of you have been
very keen to point out in the

past year and a half, I don't
really understand the
sartorial side of life.

What clothes to me are means of
staying warm, staying dry,

and not exposing your bits to
the rest of the public.
I'm supposed to wear this.
Really.

And no sense of irony at all,
I'm supposed to drive around
Italy with this on my noggin.

I'm sure this is being
done to keep everyone
else around me amused.
As have these.
These are my goggles.
Do I look ridiculous?

Or do I just look like I'm
driving an old racing car?
I certainly feel ridiculous.

The pre-start in Breacia is in
the afternoon, before the
actual start in the evening.

It buckets down with rain, but
several thousand people still

mob Daniel Day Lewis, who is
driving a Jaguar XK120.

That evening, we all line up on
a street running into the
town and wait.

People casually mill and among
hundreds of millions of pounds

of machinery and enjoy
a little sunshine.
[CAR ENGINE]
The start is intense.

For the first quarter
of a mile, Al giving
it plenty of beans.
But then it becomes a slower
procession through the streets.
We have two problems though.

One, the trip meter isn't
calibrated properly.

Two, another C-type overtakes
us less than five
miles out of town.
It won't happen again.

Then it begins to
rain and rain.

The first regularity stage
is a total shambles.

We have no idea what we're
doing and we're
placed 400th overall.

We are officially bad
at going slowly.
And we are very proud.

Later in Verona we have a
massive dice with a Porsche

550 Spider, a few million quids
worth itself, brushing

the table clothes of
the bars in places.

Let's have a little recap
of how we feel
we've fared so far.

So we now are sitting
in Verona and--
ALEX BUNCOMBE: We think.
CHRIS HARRIS: We think.
ALEX BUNCOMBE: Yeah.

CHRIS HARRIS: We just had a
wonderful dice with a 550
Spider, which got us told off.

A bit naughty, but we now know
where the line lines.
ALEX BUNCOMBE: Absolutely.

CHRIS HARRIS: I've been
driving beautifully.

Within five minutes of leaving
Breacia, we had [INAUDIBLE].
[CAR ENGINE  REVVS]

ALEX BUNCOMBE: Yeah, absolutely,
we unfortunately

somehow the calibration on our
trip was wrong, so we were

actually, and thought
we were traveling
further than we were.
So it was a nightmare.

So we had to speak to the
team, and they told
us how to sort it.
CHRIS HARRIS: We think.

ALEX BUNCOMBE: But now we're
on the right track.

CHRIS HARRIS: So we've got the
trip meter calibrated, but

then we had to sort of reset
the total distance.

ALEX BUNCOMBE: Yeah, to find out
where we were, et cetera.

And yeah, a bit of a
nightmare, but--

CHRIS HARRIS: A man is a lot
talking about at our first
regularity bit.

I didn't have a clue
what we were doing.

ALEX BUNCOMBE: Time travel
is just a nightmare.

That was our first one honestly,
but I'm sure we'll
get used to it.

CHRIS HARRIS: No, I didn't
get that at all.
But it's an adventure.

The weather has been better, but
that doesn't mean it's not
going to get worse.

ALEX BUNCOMBE: We've got
a little rain shower--

CHRIS HARRIS: I think we need
to just get on and get to
where we're going.
ALEX BUNCOMBE: Yeah.
CHRIS HARRIS: There you go.
That's the summary.
[CAR ENGINE]

We also learned not to forget
your time card at the time

check, because you'll need to
reverse back into town to
retrieve it.
[CAR ENGINES]
[CAR ENGINE]

CHRIS HARRIS: The rain is
heavier now, and the

organizers abandoned a load of
the route, sending us down the
autostrada and into Ferrara.

We're an hour early for the
finish, but they let us just

check in and head
off to some kip.

We'll have to be up again
in five hours.

That's the thing about
the Mille Miglia--

it's essentially for old money
and wonderful cars.

But it's also pretty physically
demanding.

We're knackered, but this will
be the easiest day by far.
[CAR ENGINE]
It rains again in the morning.
It this actually Wales?

Heavy grey clouds and
zillion-pound racing
Jaguars don't mix.

My goggles steam up and I have
several other excuses for
driving pretty cautiously.

It rained so hard, we can't even
run a camera on the car.

Everyone backs off, except
the Mercedes gull-wings.
They just overtake everything.

Either they are rich enough
not to care or they have
specially designed testicles.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

After squeezing through
Sanremo,
the sun peeps through.

And I think it's the first time
that Al and I realized

how truly special
this event is.

A nation of car lovers lining
the streets, endless gifts

from small villages, gorgeous
scenery, and a car that just
loves being thrashed.

I sit so low in the seat that
I have to crank my neck back
to peer over the wheel.

It goes like stink on its
short axle, call it six

seconds to 60 and
120 flat out.

The drum brakes aren't
anything like
as bad as I'd feared.

And the old shaped Dunlops are
made from rather snazzy modern
compound so they grip.
In the dry, that is.

The steering is compelling, the
four-speed box perfect and

mechanical, and the
exhaust nice.

Well, I can think of no better
way of getting tinnitus.

A four-hour stint in
the jump seat give
you a proper headache.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

The place names draw more
romantic as we pile south--
San Sepolcro, Assisi, Spoleto.

And then Al put some serious
manners on one of the faster

gull-wings before we
sprint into Rome.

Turns out, he was one of the
main event sponsors.

Next day, he says we're
both animals.
Gr.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

We arrive an hour and a half
before our check-in time,

thinking that, like the previous
night, they'll just
let us through.
They don't.

We sit in the dark car park
after a 14-hour drive in a car

with no exhaust silencers and
no windscreen for an hour.

I thought the Mille Miglia was
about driving, not waiting.

Four hours of sleep later, and
the unruly sun drags us from

the underground car park
into the start of
day three in Rome.

Neither of us will forget
this in a hurry.
[CAR ENGINE]

CHRIS HARRIS: We have the
best car in all of Rome.
It's unbelievable.
300 horsepower, 900 kilograms.
How can you not enjoy it?

The only bit we don't enjoy is
when you get there having to
wait around for an hour.
[CAR ENGINE]

We jostle our way through some
stragglers in the crisp

morning air, take a wrong
turn, almost immediately

rejoined behind all the car we'd
just overtaken, rather
embarrassingly.

And then end up in one of
those dream situations,

following three other Jaguars
in a police escort striking
out of Rome.

Losing twos, running
red lights.
Only in Italy.

First stop is a regularity
at Vallelunga circuit.

Now, neither Al or me can
comprehend averaging 28 miles

an hour around a track, so
I pull a little drift.

And then stop at the next corner
to get the time back.

The spectators erupt
with applause.
[CAR ENGINE]

Then we begin the long drag
north, over 500 miles on minor

roads, running behind police
bikes scuffling with other

horrendously invaluably
machines, and generally living

in a dream world we will
never reenter.

And then to bring us back to
reality, we overtook David
Coulthard in an SLR.
I mean, what is this?

And then we really do come
down with a bump.

Another stuffing regularity
stage.

And then we have to sit and
wait another 45 minutes at
some crappy time check.

At which point, I think we both
realized that we need to
make a decision.

You cannot sit stationary
in a C-type.
It is morally wrong.

It is now halfway through
roughly--

a little bit before halfway
through-- the final day of the
Mille Miglia.

We're sitting outside
of random trattoria
somewhere in Italy.

I couldn't tell you
where we are.

Al and I have reached
a realization.
I call it a Eureka moment.
This even is amazing.
[A CAR GOING BY HONKS]
Like that.

We've experienced things I feel
I'd never experienced.

Being led out of Rome, flat
chat in a convoy of

million-pound cars, following
a policeman who's behaving

more irresponsibly in
town than I've ever
seen in another driver.

It's not something
I want to forget.
It's amazing.
It's bucket-list stuff.

The car's amazing,
the country's
amazing, the route's amazing.

There is but one problem,
isn't there?
ALEX BUNCOMBE: That blue thing?
Red thing.

CHRIS HARRIS: Yeah, this
is called a road book.
And this dominates us.
This is today's route, OK?
There's lost and lots of it.
And you know what?

It kind of gets in the
way of the driving.

You've got to meet checkpoints
and timings, and--
ALEX BUNCOMBE: Yeah.

CHRIS HARRIS: There comes
a point, where you think

yourself, I don't want to get
somewhere and wait an
hour to finish it.

Now, maybe I'm being
a bad sport.

But what do you think we
do that from now on?

ALEX BUNCOMBE: Get
rid of that.

CHRIS HARRIS: We're just going
to drive to Breacia, which is

about 500 kilometers away,
really fast, getting involved

in a lot if dices without a
very, very valuable cause.

And have ourselves
a wicked time.
Now we're in business.
We need to make time.

We don't care about
the timing.

And we're about to enjoy
a full police
escort through Bologna.

We slice through its gridlock
center and onto a place called

Maranello, through a factory
called Ferrari, and onto a
circuit called Fiorano.

I'm banned from being
here, so Al drives.
I lower the peak of my cap.

And he executes a large skid
on the final corner.
The marshalls clap.

The run back into Breacia
is perhaps the best
road drive of my life.

We follow a Ferrari 250NM as
fast as I can drive in the

conditions after 15 hours
behind the wheel.

The car feels stronger
than ever.

But it's dark, so we have
no video footage at all.
But a bit of me likes that.

It's a memory Al and I
will share for ever.
{SPECTATORS CHEER]

When we roll across the
finish line, we are
toast, ruined and ecstatic.

[ANNOUNCER SPEAKING
IN ITALIAN]
[PEOPLE CHEER]
CHRIS HARRIS: Hey.
INTERVIEWER: How was that?

CHRIS HARRIS: The last hour
was absolutely [BEEP]
superb.

ALEX BUNCOMBE: We
had [INAUDIBLE].

CHRIS HARRIS: That little
[INAUDIBLE] the 250NM, we
stayed with it for an hour.
And we were--

ALEX BUNCOMBE: I was dying for
a piss, so I wanted to stop,

but he would get pissy, so
I didn't [INAUDIBLE].

CHRIS HARRIS: [INAUDIBLE]
honestly, when you left us, I
was [BEEP]

that is absolutely
on the money.
INTERVIEWER: Stay there.
You beat me to it, but--
CHRIS HARRIS: Oh.
[INAUDIBLE]
[CROWD CHEERING]
I want to just--
before we leave this car.

It's amazing when you drive
something for 15 hours-- we've
been in this car 15 hours--

get, we had an hour's lunch, you
do generate something of a
bond with it.

And it's impossible to describe
the amount of

detritus in here, but
we're so snug.

We've got everything
we need, and a few
things that we don't.
ALEX BUNCOMBE: Yeah.

CHRIS HARRIS: And tomorrow
morning, I think we best do it

tomorrow morning is we're not
going to get the car washed.

We're going to get up, that
downstairs to the garage and

talk you around how we used it,
where everything went, and
why it's so [BEEP]
special.

Now I'm going to go and drink so
much beer though I suspect
I might wet the bed.
ALEX BUNCOMBE: [LAUGHS]

CHRIS HARRIS: And this
was the morning
after the night before.
What a machine.
1,000 miles flat out.
And all we broke was a spoke.
The Mille Miglia isn't a race.
It's an experience.
[CAR ENGINES REVVING]

title: Driving a Jaguar C-Type on the Mille Miglia - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS
